audio_description: Hello! Welcome to Chef Dheenathayalan’s Kitchen. Today in our kitchen, we’re going to see how to make Dindigul-style Thalapakatti Biryani.

audio_description: Dindigul biryani is made using seeraga samba rice. When I was in Alangulam and See Thambi, I made Dindigul biryani in a pressure cooker. Many of you have seen it and given great comments. I’ve come back with another superb biryani.

audio_description: This recipe I know is in a fantastic style—truly amazing. Let’s definitely see how it’s made. I’ve ground small onions into a paste and set it aside. Then I’ve taken whole garam masala—about 30 grams. You might wonder why 30 grams?

audio_description: For the Thalapakatti Dindigul Chicken Biryani, the required ingredients are: 600 grams chicken, 600 grams seeraga samba rice, 2 large onions, 35 small onions (about 100 grams), 180 grams tomato, 6–8 green chilies, 100 tablespoons ginger garlic paste.

audio_description: 150 ml oil, 3 tablespoons ghee. Whole garam masala (30 grams) includes cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, star anise—keep 30 grams ready. These are the ingredients required. Let’s get into the preparation for the biryani.

audio_description: While soaking the seeraga samba rice, many people make a mistake. This rice must always be soaked properly. Some say half an hour, some say one hour. But don’t do it randomly. When you start the preparation, soak it at the correct time, so the rice doesn’t get overcooked.

audio_description: So I’m telling you clearly—first sauté about 30% of the large onions, then add the small onions and cook until about 50–60% done. After that, add the ground ginger garlic paste. For this preparation, two tablespoons of ginger garlic paste are used.

audio_description: After that, I’ve added 100 ml of curd. If the curd is too sour, you can reduce it slightly. Use curd depending on its sourness. I had slightly sour curd, so I used 100 ml. Then add chili powder and salt. That completes the masala base.

audio_description: You might ask how much water to add. For one cup of seeraga samba rice, use 1.75 cups of water. Many people have asked me not to say “just enough water”—so I’m clearly saying 1.75 cups.

audio_description: After that, I’ve added the soaked rice. When to close the lid and put it on dum (slow steam cooking)? When the rice is about 50–60% cooked. Then cover it and cook on dum. At that point, squeeze lemon juice and add it.
